title: Bhimbandh Wildlife Sanctuary
text:
Bhimbandh Wildlife Sanctuary is a <a href="wildlife%20sanctuary">wildlife sanctuary</a> in <a href="Bihar">Bihar</a> in the <a href="south-west">south-west</a> of <a href="Jamui%20District">Jamui District</a> .
Etymology.
According to <a href="Mahabharata">Mahabharata</a>; <a href="Bheema">Bheema</a>, one of the <a href="pandavas">pandavas</a>, constructed a <a href="dam">dam</a> (bandh) here and therefore it is called Bhimbandh.
Geography.
Bhimbandh Wildlife Sanctuary is located in the south west of <a href="Munger%20district">Munger district</a>. The forests cover an area or 681.99 km² on the hills and undulating tract of Kharagpur Hills. It is situated at a distance of 56 km from southern border of <a href="Munger">Munger</a>, 20 km from <a href="Jamui">Jamui</a> <a href="Railway%20Station">Railway Station</a> and 200 km from <a href="Patna%20Airport">Patna Airport</a>.
Bhimbandh is situated south of the <a href="Ganges%20River">Ganges River</a>, at the northern edge of <a href="Chota%20Nagpur%20Plateau">Chota Nagpur Plateau</a> and west of <a href="Santhal_Pargana_division">Santhal Pargana</a>. it is surrounded on all sides by densely inhabited non-forestry areas. In the valley portions and at the <a href="foothill">foothill</a>s are several <a href="hot%20spring">hot spring</a>s of which the finest are at Bhimbandh, <a href="Sita%20Kund">Sita Kund</a> and Rishi Kund. All the hot springs maintain nearly almost same <a href="temperature">temperature</a> all year round. Of them, the Bhimbandh springs have the hottest temperature (52 °C to 65 °C) and discharge (0.84-1.12 cum/sec) and constitute the best area for the exploration of geothermal energy potential.
There are number of places of tourist interest near the Sanctuary, including Rishi Kund, <a href="Sita%20Kund">Sita Kund</a>, Ha-Ha Punch Kumari, Rameshwar Kund, and Kharagpur Lake.
Climate.
The climate is normal for the <a href="Munger%20district">Munger district</a>.
There are three distinct seasons in this zone, summer (March to May), monsoon (June to September) and winter (October to February). Average annual rainfall of this district is 1146 mm.
Fauna.
Fauna include: <a href="tiger">tiger</a> (3), <a href="leopard">leopard</a> (36), <a href="peafowl">peafowl</a> (637), <a href="wild%20bear">wild bear</a> (63), <a href="Indian%20hare">Indian hare</a> (507), <a href="Langoor">Langoor</a> (3388), <a href="monkey">monkey</a> (612), sahil (57), <a href="bear">bear</a> (96), <a href="cheetal">cheetal</a> (87), <a href="barking%20deer">barking deer</a> (559), <a href="Red_junglefowl">Van Murgi</a> (863), <a href="nilgai">nilgai</a> (255), <a href="Pythonidae">python</a> (39), <a href="newala">newala</a> (36), <a href="gaur">gaur</a> (39), and <a href="hyena">hyena</a> (36) are the major fauna of the Bhimband. Other <a href="fauna">fauna</a> include the <a href="jungle%20cat">jungle cat</a>, <a href="fishing%20cat">fishing cat</a>, and <a href="leopard%20cat">leopard cat</a>. Small mammals include the rare <a href="hispid%20hare">hispid hare</a>, <a href="Indian%20gray%20mongoose">Indian gray mongoose</a>, <a href="small%20Indian%20mongoose">small Indian mongoose</a>s, <a href="large%20Indian%20civet">large Indian civet</a>, <a href="small%20Indian%20civet">small Indian civet</a>s, <a href="Bengal%20fox">Bengal fox</a>, <a href="golden%20jackal">golden jackal</a>, <a href="sloth%20bear">sloth bear</a>, <a href="Chinese%20pangolin">Chinese pangolin</a>, <a href="Indian%20pangolin">Indian pangolin</a>s, <a href="hog%20badger">hog badger</a>, <a href="Chinese%20ferret%20badger">Chinese ferret badger</a>s, and <a href="Hylopetes">particolored flying squirrel</a>.
<a href="Crocodile">Crocodile</a>s are found in "Kharagpur lake" and Kalidah near "Rameshwar kund". Among <a href="snake">snake</a>s, <a href="cobra">cobra</a> and <a href="krait">krait</a>s are of common occurrence while <a href="Pythonidae">python</a>s are occasionally seen.
Common <a href="bird">bird</a> species are <a href="peafowl">peafowl</a>, <a href="grey%20partridge">grey partridge</a>, <a href="quail">quail</a>, <a href="Malabar%20grey%20hornbill">Malabar hornbill</a>, <a href="Oriental_pied_hornbill">pied hornbill</a>, <a href="swallow">swallow</a>, <a href="nightjars">nightjars</a>, <a href="drongo">drongo</a>, <a href="paradise%20flycatcher">paradise flycatcher</a>, <a href="kingfisher">kingfisher</a>, <a href="bulbul">bulbul</a>, <a href="mynas">mynas</a>, <a href="pigeon">pigeon</a>, <a href="Common%20wood%20pigeon">wood pigeon</a>, <a href="blue%20jay">blue jay</a>, <a href="owl">owl</a>, <a href="falcon">falcon</a>, <a href="Kite%20%28bird%29">kite</a>, <a href="eastern%20imperial%20eagle">eastern imperial eagle</a>, <a href="greater%20spotted%20eagle">greater spotted eagle</a>, <a href="white-tailed%20eagle">white-tailed eagle</a>, <a href="Pallas%27s%20fish%20eagle">Pallas's fish eagle</a>, <a href="grey-headed%20fish%20eagle">grey-headed fish eagle</a>, <a href="lesser%20kestrel">lesser kestrel</a> and <a href="vulture">vulture</a>.
Birds such as the <a href="lesser%20white-fronted%20goose">lesser white-fronted goose</a>, <a href="ferruginous%20duck">ferruginous duck</a>, <a href="Baer%27s%20pochard">Baer's pochard</a> <a href="duck">duck</a> and <a href="lesser%20adjutant">lesser adjutant</a>, <a href="greater%20adjutant">greater adjutant</a>, <a href="black-necked%20stork">black-necked stork</a>, and <a href="Asian%20openbill">Asian openbill</a> <a href="stork">stork</a> migrate from <a href="Central%20Asia">Central Asia</a> to the park during winter.
The main animals found at Bhimbandh Wildlife Sanctuary are <a href="tigers">tigers</a>, <a href="panthera">panthers</a>, <a href="wild%20boars">wild boars</a>, <a href="sloth%20bear">sloth bear</a>, <a href="sambar%20deer">sambar deer</a>, <a href="Spotted%20deer">chitals</a>, <a href="four-horned%20antelope">four-horned antelope</a> and <a href="nilgais">nilgais</a>. However, the sanctuary is more famous for its bird life rather than the land animals. It is home to more than 100 species of resident birds, which stay here all year around. The number increases in the winter migratory season when there is an influx of birds from the <a href="Central%20Asia">Central Asia</a> region.
Flora.
There are two major <a href="biome">biome</a>s present in Bhimbandh, <a href="grassland">grassland</a> and forest. The <a href="sanctuary">sanctuary</a> area has mainly <a href="Sal%20tree">sal</a> forest, forest, <a href="Bamboo">Bamboo</a> forest, grassland and many small forests of many miscellaneous species of <a href="flora">flora</a>. The top <a href="Canopy%20%28forest%29">canopy</a> of Bhimbandh mainly consists "<a href="Shorea%20robusta">Shorea robusta</a>" (sal), "<a href="Diospyros%20melanoxylon">Diospyros melanoxylon</a>" (kendu), "<a href="Boswellia%20serrata">Boswellia serrata</a>" (salai), "<a href="Terminalia%20tomentosa">Terminalia tomentosa</a>" (Asan), "<a href="Terminalia_bellirica">Terminalia belliriica</a>" (Bahera), "<a href="Terminalia%20arjuna">Terminalia arjuna</a>" (Arjun), "<a href="Pterocarpus%20marsupium">Pterocarpus marsupium</a>" (Paisar). The top <a href="Canopy%20%28forest%29">canopy</a> of Bhimbandh mainly "<a href="Madhuca%20indica">Madhuca indica</a>" (Mahua) and "<a href="Holarrhena%20antidysenterica">Holarrhena antidysenterica</a>". Bhimbandh's <a href="Soil">ground</a> <a href="Flora">Flora</a> includes "<a href="Flemengia%20chappar">Flemengia chappar</a> and <a href="Zizyphus%20xylopyrus">Zizyphus xylopyrus</a>". <a href="vine">climber</a> <a href="flora">flora</a> include "<a href="Bauhinia%20vahlii">Bauhinia vahlii</a>" and "<a href="Smilex%20protifrera">Smilex protifrera</a>." Creeper <a href="flora">flora</a> includes "<a href="Butea%20superba">Butea superba</a> and <a href="Butea%20parviflora">Butea parviflora</a>."
Administration.
Administered under <a href="Munger%20district">Munger district</a>, this village lies within the Gangta police station, has an area of 4137 acres. The villagers in Bhimbandh are mainly engaged in the field of agriculture. The Government of Bihar recently allotted Rs 9 crore for the promotion of tourism in the area.
Bihar chief minister Nitish Kumar visited in 2017 and instructed the officials to channel the hot spring to use in irrigation.
Transport.
Visitors can access this place by road from Munger town or from <a href="Bhagalpur_Junction_railway_station">Bhagalpur Junction Railway Station</a>. Bariarpur station on Jamalpur Bhagalpur section is the nearest rail station as also the nearest road link on NH 80.
Road Route: Bariarpur - galimpur - Kharagpur - Gangta - Bhimbandh - Jamui.
